definitions: causing or deserving hatred and disgust; extremely unpleasant or repellent
deserving strong moral condemnation; utterly repugnant in character or action
examples: The odious smell from the dumpster nauseated everyone nearby
His odious behavior at the party offended all the guests
The dictator's odious crimes against humanity shocked the world
She found their odious treatment of workers completely unacceptable

definitions: completely lacking any scent or odor; unable to be detected through smell
examples: Carbon monoxide is an odorless gas that can be deadly
The odorless paint was perfect for the nursery room

definitions: different from what is usual, expected, or conventional; quirky and unconventional
examples: Her offbeat sense of humor delighted her creative friends
The movie's offbeat approach to storytelling won critical acclaim

definitions: feeling resentful, upset, or annoyed as a result of a perceived insult
examples: She looked deeply offended by his thoughtless remark
The offended customer demanded to speak with the manager

definitions: causing displeasure, anger, or resentment through words or actions
responsible for a crime, mistake, or undesirable situation
examples: The offending remarks were quickly removed from the website
She apologized for the offending comment during the meeting
The mechanic identified the offending part causing engine failure
The offending player was ejected from the game immediately

definitions: causing someone to feel hurt, angry, or upset; disagreeable to the senses
actively aggressive or attacking; taking the initiative in attack
used for or concerned with military or sports attack rather than defense
examples: His offensive jokes made everyone uncomfortable at dinner
The offensive odor from the factory bothered nearby residents
The team took an offensive stance from the first quarter
Her offensive tactics in negotiations surprised her opponents
The offensive weapons were stored in a secure facility
The coach emphasized offensive strategies during practice sessions

definitions: relating to an authority or public body and its duties, actions, and responsibilities
having the formal approval or authorization of a recognized authority
examples: The official report was released after thorough investigation
She received an official warning from the department head
The president made an official visit to the neighboring country
This is now the official policy of our organization

definitions: situated at sea some distance from the shore; moving away from land
located or based in a foreign country, especially for tax advantages
examples: The offshore drilling platform was visible from the beach
Strong offshore winds made sailing conditions perfect today
Many corporations keep offshore accounts in tax havens
The company moved its offshore operations to reduce costs

definitions: in an illegal position on the field according to the rules of certain sports
examples: The striker was offside when he received the pass
The referee called an offside penalty against our team

definitions: not taking place on the stage; happening behind or at the side of the stage
examples: The actors waited offstage for their entrance cue
Offstage drama often rivals what happens during performances

definitions: covered or treated with oil for lubrication, protection, or appearance
operating smoothly and efficiently, as if well-lubricated
examples: The oiled wooden floor gleamed in the afternoon sunlight
He carefully maintained his oiled leather boots every week
Their oiled teamwork made the project finish ahead of schedule
The company runs like an oiled machine under new management

definitions: containing oil or covered with oil; having a greasy consistency or appearance
unpleasantly smooth and ingratiating in manner; excessively flattering
examples: Her oily skin required special cleansing products twice daily
The mechanic's oily hands left marks on the steering wheel
His oily charm made everyone suspicious of his true intentions
The salesman's oily manner didn't convince potential buyers

definitions: having lived or existed for many years; not young or new
having existed or been in use for a long time; long-established
belonging to or associated with the past; former or previous
examples: The old man shared stories from his youth with grandchildren
Our old dog needs special care for his arthritis
They lived in an old house built in the nineteenth century
These old traditions have been maintained for generations
She occasionally meets her old colleagues for lunch downtown
His old habits are hard to break after so many years

definitions: belonging to or characteristic of former times, especially long ago
examples: In olden days people traveled by horse and carriage
The olden traditions are still celebrated in this village

definitions: having lived or existed for a greater length of time than something else
examples: His older brother graduated from college three years ago
The older generation prefers traditional methods of communication

definitions: relating to or connected with the sense of smell or the organs involved
examples: The olfactory nerves transmit smell signals to the brain
Dogs have highly developed olfactory abilities for tracking scents

definitions: relating to or supporting government by a small group of powerful people
examples: The oligarchic system concentrated power among wealthy families
Critics denounced the oligarchic tendencies of the new administration

definitions: having a yellowish-green color like that of unripe or green olives
examples: She wore an olive jacket that complemented her complexion
The olive walls created a warm atmosphere in the room

definitions: majestic in manner; superior to ordinary mortals in abilities or achievements
relating to the Olympic Games or to Mount Olympus in ancient Greece
examples: She maintained an olympian detachment from office politics
His olympian achievements in science earned him global recognition
The olympian athletes trained rigorously for four years straight
The museum displayed olympian artifacts from ancient Greece

definitions: giving the impression that something bad or unpleasant is going to happen; threatening
examples: The ominous clouds suggested an approaching storm was imminent
There was an ominous silence before the announcement came

definitions: having unlimited or very great power; able to do anything
examples: Many religions describe their deity as omnipotent and benevolent
The dictator acted as if he were omnipotent within borders

definitions: present everywhere at the same time; constantly encountered or widespread
examples: Smartphones have become omnipresent in modern daily life
The omnipresent surveillance cameras monitored every street corner

definitions: knowing everything; having unlimited knowledge or understanding
examples: The omniscient narrator knew every character's thoughts and motivations
She acted with omniscient confidence about future market trends

definitions: feeding on both plants and animals; consuming food of every kind
examples: Bears are omnivorous animals that eat fish, berries, and insects
His omnivorous reading habits included everything from comics to classics

definitions: approaching or moving toward a particular point; advancing in one's direction
examples: The driver swerved to avoid the oncoming traffic
She braced herself for the oncoming winter storm

definitions: involving a great deal of effort, trouble, or difficulty; burdensome
examples: The onerous task of data entry took several weeks
They faced onerous regulations that hindered business growth

definitions: belonging to or occurring in the past; former
examples: The onetime champion struggled to regain his former glory
This onetime industrial site is now a shopping mall

definitions: continuing to exist or develop; currently in progress
examples: The ongoing investigation has revealed new evidence this week
Their ongoing commitment to quality impressed all their clients

definitions: moving toward or located on the shore from the direction of the sea
based or located in the home country rather than abroad
examples: The onshore breeze brought relief from the summer heat
Onshore oil reserves are easier to access than offshore ones
The company moved its onshore operations back from overseas
They prefer onshore investments for greater regulatory oversight

definitions: in a legal position on the field according to the rules of certain sports
examples: The player was onside when he received the pass
Make sure you stay onside to avoid the penalty

definitions: taking place on the stage in view of an audience
examples: Her onstage presence captivated the entire audience tonight
The onstage chemistry between the actors was remarkable

definitions: not able to be seen through; not transparent or translucent
difficult or impossible to understand; obscure and unclear in meaning
examples: The opaque glass windows provided privacy from the street
She wore opaque tights under her short winter skirt
The company's opaque financial statements worried potential investors
His opaque writing style made the instructions hard to follow

definitions: allowing access, passage, or view through an empty space; not closed
available for entry or participation; accessible to all
honest and communicative; willing to talk or listen without concealment
not yet decided or settled; still under consideration
examples: The open window let fresh air into the stuffy room
She left the door open for the delivery person
The competition is open to students of all ages
The library remains open until nine o'clock every evening
She appreciated his open discussion about their relationship problems
The manager maintains an open dialogue with all employees
The position remains open until we find the right candidate
Keep an open mind about the different possibilities available

definitions: having been made accessible or available by opening
examples: The newly opened restaurant attracted crowds all week
She found an opened package on her doorstep

definitions: coming at the beginning or start of something; initial
examples: The opening ceremony impressed all the attending dignitaries
Her opening remarks set the tone for the debate

definitions: able to be used or operated; in working order and functioning properly
able to be treated by a surgical operation
examples: The old machinery is still operable after proper maintenance
Only half the elevators were operable during the renovation
The tumor was operable and successfully removed last week
Fortunately, her condition is operable with minimal risk

definitions: relating to or characteristic of opera as an art form
exaggerated or overdramatic in behavior or style
examples: Her operatic training was evident in her powerful voice
The operatic performance received standing ovations every night
His operatic gestures during the argument seemed unnecessary
She made an operatic exit from the party after the dispute

definitions: engaged in performing the activities of a business or organization
examples: The operating costs exceeded the projected budget this quarter
All operating systems require regular updates for security

definitions: in working order and ready to be used; functioning effectively
relating to the routine functioning and activities of an organization
examples: The new facility will be operational by next month
All emergency systems are operational and tested regularly
They made operational changes to improve efficiency significantly
The operational budget was approved by the board yesterday

definitions: functioning effectively; in force or effect
having the most significance or relevance in a particular situation
examples: The security system became operative at midnight yesterday
The new regulations are operative from January first
Trust was the operative word in their business relationship
Cost became the operative factor in their final decision

definitions: stubbornly holding to one's own opinions and unwilling to consider other views
examples: Her opinionated uncle dominated every family dinner conversation
The opinionated blogger refused to acknowledge any opposing viewpoints

definitions: opposed to something; acting against or in opposition
examples: The opponent forces clashed on the battlefield at dawn
She faced opponent views from several board members

definitions: occurring at a favorable or useful time; well-timed and appropriate
examples: This is an opportune moment to discuss salary increases
The rain provided an opportune excuse to leave early

definitions: exploiting opportunities with little regard for principles or consequences
examples: The opportunist politician changed positions to gain votes
His opportunist behavior alienated his former allies

definitions: exploiting chances offered by immediate circumstances without reference to principles
examples: The opportunistic investor profited from the market crash
Opportunistic infections can affect people with weakened immune systems

definitions: disagreeing with or disapproving of something; being against
examples: She remained opposed to the merger despite pressure
The opposed factions couldn't reach a compromise

definitions: in conflict or competition with; contrary or opposite in position
examples: The opposing teams shook hands after the match
Opposing views on the issue created heated debate

definitions: completely different in nature, position, or direction from something else
situated directly across from something else; facing
examples: They have opposite opinions about how to proceed
Hot and cold are opposite temperature sensations
She sat in the opposite corner of the room
The houses on opposite sides faced each other

definitions: subjected to harsh and authoritarian treatment; kept down by severe use of force
examples: The oppressed workers finally organized to demand better conditions
Oppressed minorities fought for equal rights throughout history

definitions: unjustly inflicting hardship and constraint on a group or individual
weighing heavily on the mind or spirits; causing depression or discomfort
examples: The oppressive regime silenced all forms of political dissent
Workers protested against oppressive labor conditions in factories
The oppressive heat made it difficult to work outside
An oppressive silence filled the room after the announcement
